utterances: John McCann is a columnist for the Herald-Sun in Durham, North Carolina.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
Quick - do some brain stretches because it is time for the puzzle.
And joining me now is WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle-master Will Shortz.
So, you got us thinking about five words for last week's challenge.
Remind us, what were those words?
Those five words were school, half, cupboard, Wednesday and friend.
And the challenge was to identify what specific and unusual property these five words have in common.
And I asked you to, if you get the answer, to name a sixth word that shares the property.
Well, the property is, of course, it each has a silent letter.
It's more than that - it's always the third letter that's silent.
And in addition, if you remove that third letter, what's left will always, in each case, is pronounced the same.
And other possible answers were salmon, debt, juice, subtle and aghast.
So, about 500 of our listeners figured that out, and our randomly selected winner this week is Steve Worona of Montpelier, Vermont.
So, what was the sixth word with the silent third letter you came up with?
I said to myself silent letters - what word has a lot of silent letters?
And hopefully one that I came up with would have a silent letter in the third spot and enough did.
And what was that sixth word?
And what do you do in Montpelier?
Well, so you do a whole lot of whatever you want, I suppose.
I retired from a position actually working down in the Beltway, where you guys are.
And I suppose you have more time now for puzzles.
Well, let's put your skills to the test.
Hope you have pencil and paper handy.
I'm going to give you two words - change one letter in each of them to make two new words that name things that are in the same category.
And here's a hint: in each pair, the letter that you change to - that is the new letter or the replacement letter - is the same in each pair.
For example, if I said: poked P-O-K-E-D and tummy T-U-M-M-Y, you would say poker and rummy, changing both the D in poked and the T in tummy to Rs.
Number one is venue V-E-N-U-E and mark M-A-R-K.
What letter can you change to spell something else?
It's not pines, no. Start with swelter.
That's the harder word to change a letter in.
Oh, when it's cold outside we put these on?
Your next one is grange G-R-A-N-G-E and mangy M-A-N-G-Y.
What letter do you think you'd change there?
